{{short description|Stereotype}} {{Discrimination sidebar |Social}}
The '''perpetual foreigner''' [[stereotype]] is a [[Racism in the United States|racialized]] form of [[Nativism (politics)|nativist]] [[xenophobia]] in which [[Naturalization|naturalized]] and even [[Jus soli|native-born citizens]] (including families that have lived in the country for generations) are perceived as foreign because they belong to [[minority group]]s.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z559DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA40|title=Cartographies of Race and Social Difference|last=Dei|first=George J. Sefa|last2=Hilowle|first2=Shukri|date=2018-12-04|publisher=Springer|isbn=9783319970769|language=en}}</ref>
== United States == It has been particularly applied as a negative [[Stereotypes of East Asians in the United States#Perpetual foreigner|stereotype of Asian Americans]], but it has also affected other minority groups, which have been considered to be "[[Other (philosophy)|the other]]"<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I4Mrc4PEHxQC&pg=PT192|title=Faith and Race in American Political Life|last=Jacobson|first=Robin Dale|last2=Wadsworth|first2=Nancy D.|date=2012-02-02|publisher=University of Virginia Press|isbn=9780813932057|language=en}}</ref> and therefore [[judicial aspects of race in the United States|legally unassimilable]], either historically or currently. In personal interactions, it can take the form of an act of [[microaggression]] in which a member of a minority group may be asked, "Where are you from?" It can also take the form of an explicit act of aggression in which a member of a minority group may be told, "Go back to where you came from."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jyzcuvgTaIMC&pg=PA37|title=Microaggressions in Everyday Life: Race, Gender, and Sexual Orientation|last=Sue|first=Derald Wing|date=2010-02-09|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9780470594155|language=en}}</ref> [[Black Americans]] are often told "go back to Africa" as a racial insult,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/community-conversations-blog/article232844217.html|title=I was told to 'Go Back to Africa.' Here's why I'm not going anywhere, Mr. Trump|last=Hines|first=Bea L.|date=July 19, 2019|work=Miami Herald|accessdate=21 July 2019}}</ref> despite the fact that on average, they are more likely to have a multi-generational family history in the United States than [[white Americans]] do.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Inc|first=Gallup|date=2001-07-10|title=Majority of Americans Identify Themselves as Third Generation Americans|url=https://news.gallup.com/poll/4621/Majority-Americans-Identify-Themselves-Third-Generation-Americans.aspx|access-date=2020-08-11|website=Gallup.com|language=en}}</ref>
The [[U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] defines workplace comments like "[[Go back where you came from]]" as a potentially illegal form of ethnic harassment.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/eeoc-go-back-where-you-came-from-discrimination-federal-law-trump-tweets/|title=U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission specifically lists "go back to where you came from" as example of discrimination|last=Silverstein|first=Jason|date=July 17, 2019|work=CBS News|accessdate=19 July 2019}}</ref> The message conveys a sense that the person is "not supposed to be there, or that it isn't their place," and it is often encountered when the minority person is "speaking out in predominantly white spaces."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/16/us/politics/aoc-trump-tlaib-omar-pressley.html|title=The Painful Roots of Trump's 'Go Back' Comment|last=Rogers|first=Katie|date=July 16, 2019|work=The New York Times|accessdate=17 July 2019}}</ref>
[[Hate crimes]], such as the [[murder of Vincent Chin]], are described as the most brutal form of the perpetual foreigner syndrome.<ref>Wu, Frank H. "Where are you really from? Asian Americans and the perpetual foreigner syndrome." ''Civil Rights Journal'', vol. 6, no. 1, 2002, p. 14.</ref>
== Post-Soviet states == [[Crimean Tatars]] are an indigenous people of Crimea with clearly established pre-Golden Horde Scythian, Greek, and Goth roots, but authorities and nativists long have treated them as perpetual foreigners. When Crimean Tatars [[deportation of the Crimean Tatars|who had been forcibly exiled in the Stalin era]] attempted to return to Crimea before [[perestroika]], they were frequently met with severe hostility by officials who took violent measures to keep them out and had orders to prevent them from returning to their native land. Meanwhile, Russian publications literally referred to deported Crimean Tatars returning to the places of their birth as foreigners.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1jbHAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA82|title=Constructing Ethnopolitics in the Soviet Union: Samizdat, Deprivation and the Rise of Ethnic Nationalism|last=Zisserman-Brodsky|first=Dina|date=2003|publisher=Springer|year=|isbn=9781403973627|location=|pages=82–83|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://comments.ua/politics/341390-vlasti-krima-schitayut-krimskih.html|title=Власти Крыма считают крымских татар диаспорой|date=2012-05-30|website=Комментарии Украина|language=ru|access-date=2019-10-02}}</ref>
== Haitians in the Dominican Republic ==
{{See also|Haitians in the Dominican Republic}}
Before 2010, the [[Constitution of the Dominican Republic]] generally granted citizenship to anyone born in the country, except children of diplomats and persons "in transit".<ref name="kirksemple" /> The 2010 constitution was amended to define all undocumented residents as "in transit".<ref name="kirksemple" /> On September 23, 2013, the Dominican Republic Constitutional Court issued a ruling that retroactively applied this definition to 1929,<ref name="randallarchibold">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/24/world/americas/dominicans-of-haitian-descent-cast-into-legal-limbo-by-court.html|title=Dominicans of Haitian Descent Cast Into Legal Limbo by Court|work=The New York Times|date=24 October 2013|first=Randal C.|last=Archibold}}</ref> the year Haiti and the Dominican Republic formalized the border.<ref name="rojas">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-dominicanrepublic-citizenship-idUSBRE99B01Z20131012|title=Dominican court ruling renders hundreds of thousands stateless|work=Reuters|date=12 October 2013|first=Ricardo|last=Rojas}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kushner |first1=Jacob |title=Birthright Denied |date=4 September 2015 |url=https://www.momentmag.com/birthright-denied/ |publisher=Moment Magazine |accessdate=12 June 2019}}</ref> The decision stripped Dominican citizenship from about 210,000 people who were born in the Dominican Republic after 1929 but are descended from undocumented immigrants from Haiti.<ref name="rojas" /> Many Haitians born in the Dominican Republic do not have Haitian citizenship and have never been to Haiti;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2015/06/17/415274544/haitians-face-deportation-from-dominican-republic-as-deadline-nears|title=Haitians Face Deportation From Dominican Republic As Deadline Nears|work=NPR|date=17 June 2015}}</ref> hence the decision rendered them at least temporarily [[Statelessness|stateless]].<ref name="kirksemple">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/18/nyregion/dominican-courts-ruling-on-citizenship-stirs-emotions-in-new-york.html|title=Dominican Court's Ruling on Citizenship Stirs Emotions in New York|work=The New York Times|date=17 October 2013|first=Kirk|last=Semple}}</ref><ref name="randallarchibold" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ijdh.org/2013/09/topics/immigration-topics/dominican-court-ruling-strips-haitians-citizenship/|title=DR Court Strips Citizenship from Dominican-born Haitians|publisher=}}</ref>
